metadata.title: Detection and isolation of false data injection attack for smart grids via unknown input observers
metadata.abstract:
The emergence of cyber-physical attacks brings a key challenge to the existing system integrity protection schemes (SIPSs) of smart grids. As one of typical cyber-physical attacks, false data injection attacks (FDIAs) can bypass the existing Kalman filter-based 
-detector detection techniques in SIPSs. To improve the detection performance against the FDIAs in SIPSs, this study proposes an unknown input observer (UIO)-based detection and isolation method. Taking the stealthy characteristics of FDIAs into account, this study presents a set of UIOs to detect the FDIA based on the internally physical dynamics. Furthermore, a UIO-based detection and isolation algorithm against the FDIAs is proposed based on the feature of residuals generated by UIOs. To detect the cyber attacks quickly and avoid missing detection, an adaptive threshold is designed to replace the precomputed threshold by taking the model linearised error and disturbance into account. Finally, comprehensive simulation results on the proposed algorithm are carried out, and the effectiveness of improving the detection performance in SIPSs is verified.

grobid.contents:
Detection and isolation of false data injection attack for smart grids via unknown input observers


Xiaoyuan Luo xyluo@ysu.edu.cn 
School of Electrical Engineering
Yanshan University
066004QinhuangdaoPeople's Republic of China

Xinyu Wang 
School of Electrical Engineering
Yanshan University
066004QinhuangdaoPeople's Republic of China

Xueyang Pan 
School of Electrical Engineering
Yanshan University
066004QinhuangdaoPeople's Republic of China

Xinping Guan 
School of Electronic, Information and Electrical Engineering
Shanghai Jiao Tong University
200240ShanghaiPeople's Republic of China

Detection and isolation of false data injection attack for smart grids via unknown input observers
10.1049/iet-gtd.2018.5139Received on 22nd March 2018 Revised 7th December 2018 Accepted on 18th January 2019 E-First on 26th March 2019IET Generation, Transmission & Distribution Special Issue: Emerging Trends in System Integrity Protection Schemes (SIPS) for Improving the Performance of Smart Grid
The emergence of cyber-physical attacks brings a key challenge to the existing system integrity protection schemes (SIPSs) of smart grids. As one of typical cyber-physical attacks, false data injection attacks (FDIAs) can bypass the existing Kalman filter-based χ 2 -detector detection techniques in SIPSs. To improve the detection performance against the FDIAs in SIPSs, this study proposes an unknown input observer (UIO)-based detection and isolation method. Taking the stealthy characteristics of FDIAs into account, this study presents a set of UIOs to detect the FDIA based on the internally physical dynamics. Furthermore, a UIO-based detection and isolation algorithm against the FDIAs is proposed based on the feature of residuals generated by UIOs. To detect the cyber attacks quickly and avoid missing detection, an adaptive threshold is designed to replace the precomputed threshold by taking the model linearised error and disturbance into account. Finally, comprehensive simulation results on the proposed algorithm are carried out, and the effectiveness of improving the detection performance in SIPSs is verified.

Introduction

As a typical cyber-physical system, smart grids achieve the cooperative operation between cyber and physical components for the generation, transmission, and distribution of power to consumers. Most prominently, the intelligent management in Supervisor Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) enhances the efficiency and reliability of system security protection schemes (SIPSs). Meanwhile, the openness and intelligence also make the smart grids more vulnerable to various kinds of cyber-physical attacks [1][2][3][4]. The emergence of cyber-physical attacks may cause unwanted relay operations and controls which initiate cascade tripping leading to grid system collapse. In the face of the risks brought by cyber-physical attacks, enhancing the reliability of SIPSs has become important to the security of smart grids.

In recent years, a lot of work on the SIPSs of smart grids has been devoted by many scholars in [5][6][7]. Inspired by these works, the impacts of the latest cyber-physical attacks on the generation, transmission, and distribution of power system were investigated in [8][9][10]. In [8], denial of service attack against the power network was proposed. It disrupts the availability of communication channel resources. Dynamic load alter attack attempts to disrupt the grid through circuit overflow by controlling and changing the unsecured loads [9]. In [10], a replay attack was designed by hijacking the sensor readings for a certain amount of time. It is injected into the power system through repeated data. Compared with cyber-physical attacks in [8][9][10], the false data injection attack (FDIA) aims to disrupt the normal operation of generation. Moreover, the attacker can fool the current SIPSs by injecting a bank of false attack sequences into sensor measurements [11,12]. Therefore, it is more difficult to detect and isolate the FDIA by the existing state estimation-based detection techniques in SIPSs.

With the incorporation of the wide-area measurement system in smart grids, Rimorov et al. proposed some effective dynamic state estimation methods in SIPSs [13,14]. Based on these works, the KF-based state estimation detection techniques are proposed to detect the cyber-physical attacks by comparing the detection residuals with the precomputed threshold [8][9][10]. However, since only measurements are used for state estimation, Kalman filter (KF)-based bad data detection technique could be bypassed by the FDIA [15][16][17]. For FDIA detection, some scholars have studied how the FDIA are injected fraudulently into smart grids [18,19]. In [18], a method for the generation of model grids was developed. Additionally, the authors of [19] further proposed an optimal attack model to describe the process of FDIA. Inspired by the above researches, some effective detection methods in SIPSs for stealthy FDIA were proposed, e.g. [20][21][22]. Ashok et al. in [20] proposed an online anomaly detection algorithm by utilising load forecasts, generation schedules and synchrophasor data to detect measurement anomalies. In [21], the authors proposed a collaborative intrusion detection mechanism against FDIA by considering the constrained computation and storage resources of a smart meter. Also, a distributed sequential detector-based adaptive sampling technique was developed to detect FDIA in [22]. However, the proposed detection methods in [20][21][22] are limited to the set of detection threshold, which may lead to missing detection. Moreover, local events leading to cascade failures may be undetected because the internally physical dynamics of grid systems are not taken into account [23]. Furthermore, the isolation of the FDIA problem is still not solved in [20][21][22]. At present, there are few works on the isolation of the FDIA. In [24], the authors proposed a prediction-based detection and location scheme against the FDIA. Due to the limitation of the detection threshold, the FDIA may be missed. To enhance the detection performance against the FDIA in SIPSs, developing a suitable detection and isolation method is crucial to the security of smart grids.

To enhance the detection performance against the FDIA in SIPSs, this paper proposes an unknown input observer (UIO)-based detection and isolation method. Different from the measurementbased grid models in [20][21][22], a continuous linear time-invariant (LTI) dynamic model of a smart grid is set up by considering the physical dynamics. Considering the deceptive characteristics of FDIA in [18,19], a UIO-based detection scheme is proposed based on the internally physical dynamics. To detect the cyber attack more quickly and avoid missing detection, this work presents an adaptive threshold to replace the precomputed threshold by taking the model linearised error and disturbance into account. Motivated by our prior works in [25,26], a UIO-based cyber-attack detection and isolation algorithm is proposed, based on the characteristics of the UIO-based residuals.

The remaining of the paper is organised as follows. The problem formulation is formulated by using a graph theory-based continuous LTI grid model in Section 2. The UIO-based detection and isolation scheme method against FDIA for smart grids is presented in Section 3. The numerical simulation results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed detection and isolation algorithm in Section 4. Section 5 concludes this paper.


Preliminaries and problem formulation

In this section, a continuous LTI grid model is set up based on graph theory and two kinds of common attack models of a random attack and false data injection attack are described, respectively. Finally, problem formulation is presented.


Dynamic grid model

As stated in [27,28], the change caused by cyber-physical attacks is always reflected in the voltage or current phase angle. Thus, the dynamic grid model by considering the phase angle of the bus is set up as follows.

List of symbols in the grid model 


Graph theory:

In a networked grid system, the topology of all buses is usually represented by a graph. Before giving the dynamic grid model, some basic concepts concerning graph theory are reviewed [29]. Consider a directed graph G′ V, ξ with n interconnected nodes, where V = V 1 , …, V n and ξ ⊂ V * V denote the node set and edge set, respectively. Let ξ i j ∈ ξ denote the directed edge between nodes i and j. Define Z i = j ∈ V : i, j ∈ ξ as the neighborhood set of i, where their nodes i, j are adjacent nodes. The adjacent weighted matrix can be defined as
Q = a 11 ⋯ a 1n ⋯ ⋱ ⋯ a n1 ⋯ a nn (1) with a i j = λ, j ∈ Z i 0, j ∉ Z i or j = i
where λ denotes the edge weight. For the directed graph G′ V, ξ , the degree matrix Δ ∈ R n × n is a diagonal matrix and its corresponding elements can be defined as
Δ i j = deg − i , i = j 0, i ≠ j(2)
with
deg − i = ∑ j ∈ V i Q i j ,
where deg − i is the out-degree of a node i . Thus, the Laplacian matrix of the Graph G′ can be defined as
Γ G′ = Δ − Q,(3)
where Γ G′ ∈ R n × n is a symmetric positive semidefinite matrix. In the following, an example of understanding is provided to illustrate the above concepts. Example 1: Figs. 1a and b denote the IEEE 9-bus power grid and its corresponding 9-node connection topology diagram, respectively.

The weighted adjacent matrix Q and degree matrix Δ can be obtained as  Thus, Γ G′ can be obtained using (3). In this paper, we focus on the connection relationship between the nodes, and some other properties of the Graph G′ can be seen in [29].


Physical dynamic grid model:

Consider a smart grid system with generators, generator terminal buses indexed by g 1 , . . . , g n and b 1 , . . . , b n and b n + 1 , . . . , b n + m , respectively. It is assumed that n buses are connected to synchronous motors or generators in the power network. Then, the swing equations of dynamics located in the bus i can be described as [30] δ˙i = w i t , i = 1, 2, …, n
Ē i ẇ i = P Mi − P i j t − D i w i t(4)
For a lossless power system, P i j t can be expressed as
P i j t = ∑ j ∈ N i k i j sin δ i t − δ j t(5)
Since the relative rotor angle differences are sufficiently small, (4) can be linearised as
Ē i δ¨i t + D i δ i t = g i ′ t + u i t(6)
with [31,32], the linear and non-linear grid models have some common parameters, which does not depend on the operating point values. Moreover, under the usual assumptions all angular differences are small and that the network is lossless, a linear small-signal model can be derived from the non-linear model (4).
g′ i t = − ∑ j ∈ N i k i j sin δ i t − δ j t u i t = P Mi Remark 1: As stated in
Since the networked grid system can be considered as G′ V, ξ with N = V nodes, where each bus corresponds to a node in the graph. Then, the grid model of (6) can be written as
x˙t = Ax t + Bu t + B d d t(7)
with
A = 0 N I N −ĒΓ −Ē D , B = Ē 0 N , u t = P M1 , …, P MN T , Ē = diag 1 m 1 , …, 1 m N , D = diag d 1 , . . . , d N where x t = δ 1 t , . . . , δ N t , δ˙1 t , . . . , δ˙N t T ,
A and B d are matrices of appropriate dimensions, respectively, B d d t denotes the external disturbance and is norm bounded, and Γ is the Laplacian matrix of Graph G′ V, ξ and denotes the connection relationship among the buses.

Remark 2: For (7), we use Δ 1 = αx to express the model linearised error, which is the higher-order deviation term in the linearisation of (4). Moreover, it is assumed that the linearised error is norm bounded.


Attack description

Usually, the attacker disrupts the normal operation of the smart grid system by falsifying some sensor or actuator readings in PMUs. As shown in Fig. 2, SCADA is in charge of collecting field measurement data and sending them to the state estimator in the control centre. Through comparing the estimations of measurements, the control centre can make control decisions to judge whether there exists a cyber-attack injected into the grid system. From Fig. 2, one can find that the attacker directly injects the random attack on PMU2 to destroy the stability of the smart grid system. However, to implement FDIA, the attacker needs to collect the relevant attack information (PMU1 and PMU3) to design false attack sequences S bad and inject them into generator bus PMU2.

Before describing two kinds of typical cyber attack, random attack and FDIA, we introduce some basic knowledge about KFbased χ 2 -detector state estimation detection technique. It compares the actual meter readings with the estimated values to generate a set of residuals, and then an alarm will be triggered when the residual surpasses the precomputed threshold.

As stated in [14], the expression of detection residual is described as
R′ a t = y t − Lx t ,(8)
where R′ a t is the residual at the time t, and L is the Jacobian matrix, which depends on the topology matrix of the grid system. Then, the corresponding residual-based detection rule against cyber attack is defined as follows:
R′ a t ≥ W attack R′ a t < W no attack ,(9)
where W is the precomputed threshold.

i. Random attack: This attack aims at destroying the stability of the smart grid system without considering the bad data detection of control centre [11]. The random attack model is described as
y′ t = C t x t + y¯a t(10)
where y′ t and x t are the observation and state under random attack, respectively, and y¯a t denotes the unknown input by the adversary. ii. False data injection attack: The attacker keeps the FDIA covert by designing a set of false data attack sequences S bad . The corresponding FDIA model is given as follows:
y′ t = υ t + δy a t (11) with υ t = C t x t , δ = γ 1 0 0 0 ⋱ 0 0 0 γ m ,
where y a t and υ t are the unknown inputs generated by the attacker and the measurement, respectively, δ is the sensor diagonal selection matrix, and γ i is equal to 1 if and only if i ∈ S bad and zero otherwise. Remark 3: As stated in [11], the attacker can steal the sensor data from the control centre by using the Trojan Horse network intrusion technology. Based on this information, a set of FDIA sequences y a t in (11)  For the control centre in the grid system, the residual measurement vector of the power model with the FDIA in [11] is given as
∥ R′ a t ∥ = ∥ υ + δy a t − L x + ρ ∥ = ∥ υ − L x + δy a t − L ρ ∥ = ∥ R′ t + δy a t − L ρ ∥ ≤ ∥ R′ t ∥ + ∥ η ∥ (12) with ∥ η ∥ = ∥ δy a t − L ϱ ∥,
where R a , R′, a and ϱ are the residual measurement vectors with the malicious attack, the measurement residual vector, the attack vector and the change caused by the cyber attack, respectively.

The attacker can design false data attack sequences in [11] to satisfy the following equality constraint:
δy a t − L ϱ = 0.(13)
Thus, the residual measurement vector satisfies the following relationship:
∥ R′ a t ∥ = ∥ R′ t ∥ + ∥ η ∥ ≤ W .(14)
We can find that FDIA can introduce very small state estimation error without triggering an alarm. Namely, the emergency of FIDA brings a key challenge to the existing SIPSs of the smart grid. The following example is given to illustrate the steady performance of FDIA.

Example 2: Let us consider an IEEE 9-bus smart grid system, as shown in Fig. 1a. It is assumed that the random attack is injected on the PMU2 at a time instant t = 180 s. The corresponding matrices A, B, and C are given in the Appendix and the FDIA sequence is the same as that of [11]. As shown in Fig. 3a, the differences between the estimated values and measured values tend to infinity, i.e. lim t → ∞ sup ∥ x a t − x t ∥ = ∞, ∥ R a ′ t ∥ < W, t = 0, 1, …, n. However, the detection residual r a ′ t never exceeds the precomputed threshold W, as shown in Fig. 3b. One can find that the local meter data has been falsified, but the control centre cannot successfully detect the FDIA. Towards this end, this paper proposes a UIO-based detection and isolation methods to improve the detection performance in SIPSs of smart grid in the next section.


Problem formulation

Considering the cyber-attack injected to the grid system, the physical dynamics of the smart grid system (7) can be rewritten as
x˙t = Ax t + Bu t + B d d(t) y(t) = Cx(t) + F f (t) .(15)
where x t ∈ R n , u t ∈ R r , f t ∈ R m , d t ∈ R q and y t ∈ R p are state vector, input vector, attack vector, disturbance vector and output vector, respectively, A, B, C and B d are matrices of appropriate dimensions, the term F f (t) denotes the unknown cyber attack with F ∈ R p × m being full column rank. Before solving the problem, we first define attack detectability and isolability for system (15) as follows [33].

Definition 1: For the given grid system (15), if the
rank sI − A 0 C F = n + m .(16)
for almost all s ∈ ℂ, the attack vector f t = f 1 t , .

. . , f m t T can be detected and isolated. Remark 4: Note that (16) implies each input will produce a change in the output. Moreover, each input has its own corresponding output.


UIO-Based detection and isolation method against the FDIA

In this section, a UIO-based detection and isolation method is proposed to enhance the detection performance against the FIDA in SIPSs. Also, a robust adaptive threshold will be presented to replace the precomputed threshold to detect the cyber attack quickly while avoiding missing detection. Finally, a UIO-based detection and isolation algorithm will be further developed.


Design of UIO for the smart grid system

Before designing UIO for system (15), a lemma is needed.

Lemma 1: There exists a UIO if and only if system (15) satisfies the following two conditions:
i. rank CB d = rank B d ii. H * = A − B d CB d T CB d −1 CB d T CA, C H * is detectable,
The detailed proof of Lemma 1 can be seen in [34]. To detect and isolate the cyber attack, this paper decomposes the attack matrix F, output matrix C, attack vector f (t) and output vector y(t), respectively. Then the smart grid system (15) with the cyber attack can be decomposed as
x˙t = Ax t + Bu t + B d d(t)(17)y −i (t) = C −i x(t) + F −i f −i (t)(18)y i (t) = C i x(t) + F i f i (t)(19)
where of y(t), C −i is obtained by deleting the ith row of C and y −i (t) is obtained by deleting the ith component of y(t), respectively. For the grid system in (17) and (18), the form of unknown input observer is designed as  (20) is called the UIO. Remark 5: One can find that the residual from the designed UIO r −i t is not sensitive to the attack injected into the ith sensor, but sensitive to attacks injected in the other sensors.
F i is the ith row of F, f i (t) is the ith component of f (t), F −i is obtained by deleting the ith row of F and f −i (t) is obtained by deleting the ith component of f (t), C i is the ith row of C, y i (t) is the ith componentz˙t = H −i z t + G −i u t + N −i y −i t x^t = z t + M −i y −i t r −i t = y −i t − C −i x^t = I − C −i M y −i t − C −i z t ,(20)
Let e t = x t − x^t , and then from (17)- (20), one can obtain
e˙t = Ax t + Bu t + B d d(t) − H −i z −i t + G −i u −i t + N −i y −i t = A − M −i C −i − N −i C −i e t − H −i − A − M −i C −i − N −i C −i z t − T −i B + M −i C −i B − B u t −N 1 F −i f −i (t) − M −i F −i f˙− i (t) − M −i C −i B d − B d d t(21)
with
N −i = N 1 + N 2 , G −i = T −i B
When no cyber-attack exist in the system (15), (21) can be rewritten as
e˙t = A − M −i C −i − N −i C −i e t − H −i − A − M −i C −i − N −i C −i z t − T −i B + M −i C −i B − B u t − N 2 − A − M −i C −i − N −i C −i H −i y −i t − M −i C −i B d − B d d t(22)
When e t → 0, it means x t → z t . Then we obtain lim t → ∞ e t = 0.
lim t → ∞ A − M −i C −i −N −i C −i e t − H −i − A −M −i C −i −N −i C −i z t − T −i B + M −i C −i B − B u t − N 2 − A −M −i C −i −N −i C −i H −i y −i t − M −i C −i B d − B d d t = 0(23)
From (23) Re λ H −i < 0
H −i − A − M −i C −i − N −i C −i = 0(24)T −i B + M −i C −i B − B = 0 (26) N 2 − A − M −i C −i − N −i C −i H −i = 0 (27) M −i C −i B d − B d = 0,(25)
where λ H −i represents the eigenvalues of a matrix H −i , and Re x denotes the real part of the variable x, respectively. Remark 6: Conditions in (24)-(28) guarantee the error of the designed observer stable. Condition (28) ensures that the unknown disturbance can be decoupled from the residual signal.

Moreover, to achieve the decoupling from the unknown input, the constraint condition of N −i needs to satisfy
N −i F −i f −i (t) ≠ 0.(29)
The detailed proof of condition (29) can be seen in [35]. Condition (29) ensures that the residuals generated by UIO are sensitive to the cyber attack. Remark 7: To detect the FDIA, the UIO is designed by taking the internally physical dynamic into account. Moreover, by system decoupling, the residual generated by the UIO is not sensitive to its node attack itself, but sensitive to other node attacks.


Design of adaptive threshold

To detect cyber-attack quickly and avoid missing detection, an adaptive threshold is designed to replace the precomputed threshold.

For the grid system in (17) and (18), the following residual generation is considered:
x˙t = Ax t + Bu t + B d d(t) y −i (t) = C −i x(t) + F −i f −i (t) r −i t = C −i e − N 1 F −i f −i (t) − M −i F −i f˙− i (t) .(30)
Based on (30), the residual evaluation function is obtained
∥ r(t) ∥ 2 = ∥ r e (t) + r f i (t) ∥ 2 (31) with ∥ r(t) ∥ 2 = ∫ t 1 t 2 r T t r t dt , r e (t) = r(t) f −i = 0 , r f −i (t) = r(t) e = 0 .
In the process of designing the adaptive threshold, we consider that the power system is the attack-free case. From (29), one can obtain ∥ r(t) ∥ 2 = ∥ r e (t) ∥ 2 .

Here we consider the model linearised error Δ 1 , and then (31) can be rewritten as
∥ r(s) ∥ 2 = ∥ r e (s) ∥ 2 = ∥ y^(s) − y(s) ∥ 2 ≤ ∥ C −i ∥ 2 ∥ sI − H −i −1 κ +M −i C −i Δ 1 − sI − A − α −1 ζ ∥ 2 (33) with κ = G −i u(s) + N −i C −i Δ 1 , ζ = Bu(s) + B d d(s) .
Choose J th (t) = sup w ≥ 0 ∥ r(t) ∥ 2 as the adaptive threshold described as follows:
J th (t) = sup w ≥ 0 ∥ C −i ∥ 2 ∥ jwI − H −i −1 κ +M −i C −i Δ 1 − jwI − A − α −1 ζ ∥ 2 .
(34) Remark 8: To address the limitation of detection threshold in [20][21][22], this section computes the adaptive threshold instead of the traditional precomputed threshold by taking the model linearised error and disturbance into account. By using the proposed detection threshold, the control centre can detect the cyber-physical attack quickly and avoid missing detection.


UIO-based detection and isolation algorithm

In this subsection, the UIO-based detection and isolation algorithm against FDIA is proposed. The theoretical basis of the proposed algorithm is given as follows: firstly, a bank of UIOs for the grid system (17) and (18) are designed. Next, a set of residuals r i t , i = 1, 2, …, n are obtained correspondingly. Then, by using (34), the adaptive threshold J th t is computed. By comparing the residuals with the adaptive threshold, the control centre can judge the bus in which cyber attack may be injected. If ∥ r i t ∥ 2 < J th t , there is no undetected unknown cyber attack in the power system. If ∥ r i t ∥ 2 < J th t , ∥ r j t ∥ 2 ≥ J th t for j = 1, 2, …, n, there exists a cyber attack at the bus i. More detailed process can be seen in Algorithm 1 (see Fig. 4). It is noted that this paper considers the only the one-attack case. For detecting and isolating multiple cyber attacks, we can repeat the above mentioned UIO-based detection and isolation algorithm for each potential bus being injected cyber attack.

Remark 9: By using the proposed Algorithm 1 (Fig. 4), one can obtain a set of residuals generated by the UIOs. Then, compared with the designed adaptive threshold, the cyber attack can be detected. Furthermore, based on the characteristics of residuals, the cyber attack can be further isolated by using the proposed Algorithm 1 (Fig. 4).


Simulation

In this section, the simulations are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the UIO-based detection and isolation method against the cyber-physical attacks on the IEEE 9-bus grid system. In the following two cases are implemented to show that the proposed detection and isolation algorithm can effectively improve the detection performance in SIPS. Case 1: The detection and isolation against the random attack using the UIO-based detection method. Case 2: The detection and isolation against the FDIA using the KF-based χ 2 -detector state estimation and UIO-based detection method, respectively. Case 1 aims to demonstrate that the proposed scheme reduces the detection time of cyber-physical attacks effectively by using the adaptive thresholds. Compared with the KF-based Euclidean detector technique, the control centre can detect the FDIA more quickly and avoid missing detection by using the proposed UIO-based detection method, as shown in Case 2. The corresponding matrices A, B and C are given in the Appendix and the topological parameters and the generators dynamic coefficients m i and d i are chosen the same as that in [36].


Case 1: random attack detection and isolation via UIO

It is assumed that a random attack is injected on bus 1 starting t = 250 s. As shown in Fig. 5, the system phase angle is changed on δ 1 . By applying Algorithm 1 (Fig. 4), a bank of UIOs as in (19) is designed for buses b 1 , b 2 , b 3 , b 4 , b 5 and b 6 . By computing the differences between the measured state values and their observed state values, a set of residuals r 1 − r 6 are obtained, as shown in Figs. 6a-i. In order to make the computational process more tractable, the random attack sequence we adopt is the sinusoidal function as follows:
y a t = Ãsin Bx(35)
where Ã and B are appropriate values, respectively. Obviously, one can find that the corresponding residual of bus 1 never surpasses the adaptive threshold starting t = 250 s, as shown in Fig. 6a. From Figs. 6b-i, one can observe that all the corresponding residuals r 2 − r 9 surpass the adaptive threshold starting t = 251 s, but surpass the precomputed threshold after t = 274 s. Specially, it is obvious that the random attack can be detected earlier by the adaptive thresholds than the precomputed threshold. In addition, based on the characteristics of the UIO-  residual, the random attack occurred on the bus 1 can be further isolated by using Algorithm 1 (Fig. 4).


Case 2: FDIA detection and isolation via UIOs

It is assumed that a false data attack sequence is injected on the generator bus 6 starting at t = 470 s. The false data attack sequence in [11] is given as follows:
y a n + t = y a t − λ i + 1 ϝ y *(36)
where n is the dimension of state space, y * = Cl, l is the eigenvector of A, λ ≥ 1, ϝ = max k = 0, …, n − 1 ∥ Δr ∥ and Δr = r a − r. The detection of FDIA by using the KF-based Euclidean detector method and UIO-based detection and isolation method are presented in the following.


FDIA detection and isolation via Euclidean detector method:

Under the FDIA, the phase angle is changed as shown in Fig. 7. By designing a set of KFs for the IEEE 9-bus grid system, we can obtain a bank of residuals shown in Figs. 8a-i, respectively. The corresponding parameters under KF-based Euclidean detector state estimation are taken from [37]. As shown in Fig. 7, one can find that the phase angles of bus 6 have been changed. Namely, the attacker successfully injects the FDIA into the grid system. From Fig. 8, one can find that only the detection residual R 6 t surpasses the precomputed threshold W starting t = 385 s. In other words, the injected FDIA is detected by the KF-based Euclidean detector detection technique. However, we can find that the detection time of the FDIA is too long, And the FDIA can be missed detection due to the set of the precomputed threshold via the KF-based Euclidean detector detection technique, as shown in Fig. 8f. In the following, we will show the effectiveness of the proposed UIO-based detection and isolation method over the KF-based Euclidean detector. 4.2.2 FDIA detection and isolation UIO-based adaptive threshold scheme: According to Algorithm 1 (Fig. 4), we design a bank of UIOs as the form of (20) for all buses. Then, a bank of the residuals r 1 − r 9 is obtained, as shown in Figs. 8a-i. Moreover, the corresponding change of the phase angles δ 6 is shown in Fig. 7. As shown in Fig. 8, all residuals exceed the adaptive threshold J th t except the residual r 6 , starting at t = 351 s. By using Algorithm 1 (Fig. 4), one can find that the residual r 6 t is not sensitive to the sixth sensor attack, but sensitive to the other sensor attacks as shown in Figs. 8a-i. Thus, the FDIA can be detected and isolated via Algorithm 1 (Fig. 4). Also, one can further find that the residuals above do not exceed the precomputed threshold, as shown in Figs. 8a-e and g-i. It also indicates that using the adaptive thresholds instead of the precomputed threshold can also avoid missing detection, which is useful and meaningful in practical cyber-attack detection for smart grids.

As shown in the above simulation studies, the proposed detection and isolation algorithm against the cyber-physical attacks can effectively enhance the detection performance in SIPSs in smart grids.


Conclusion

To improve the detection performance against the FDIAs in SIPSs for smart grids, a UIO-based detection and isolation method is proposed in this paper. An algorithm of detection and isolation FDIA in smart grids by using the designed UIOs, is proposed. Furthermore, to detect the cyber-attack quickly and avoid missing detection, an adaptive threshold is computed to replace the precomputed threshold by taking model linearised error into account. Finally, simulations on the IEEE 9-bus grid system demonstrate to the effectiveness of the proposed UIO-based detection and isolation method in improving the security of the protection operations.
